output.conclusion: This course provides a foundational understanding of signals and systems, equipping you with the necessary tools to analyze and manipulate signals in various applications. Further study in specialized areas like digital signal processing or communication systems is highly recommended.
output.courseTitle: Signals and Systems: A Beginner's Guide
output.introduction: Welcome to Signals and Systems! This course is designed for beginners with little to no prior knowledge of the subject. We will explore the fundamental concepts of signals and systems, focusing on building a strong intuitive understanding through clear explanations and examples. Each module is designed to be concise and easily digestible, requiring approximately 10 minutes of reading time.

chapters.description: Introduction to signals: definition, examples (audio, video, sensor data), classification (continuous-time, discrete-time, analog, digital).
Amplitude scaling, time shifting, time scaling, signal addition, signal multiplication. Examples with simple signals.
Unit step function, unit impulse function, exponential signals, sinusoidal signals. Graphical representation and basic properties.
Introduction to systems: definition, examples (amplifiers, filters, controllers), block diagram representation.
Linearity, time-invariance, causality, stability. Simple examples to illustrate each property.
Introduction to Linear Time-Invariant (LTI) systems. Importance of LTI systems in signal processing.
Introduction to convolution. Convolution sum for discrete-time signals. Simple examples.
Commutativity, associativity, distributivity of convolution. Understanding these properties.
Convolution as the output of an LTI system. Impulse response and its significance.
Introduction to Fourier Series. Representing periodic signals as a sum of sinusoids.
Brief overview of how to calculate Fourier Series coefficients. Focus on understanding the concept.
Examples of Fourier Series applications: signal analysis, harmonic analysis.
Introduction to the Fourier Transform. Extending Fourier Series to non-periodic signals.
Linearity, time shifting, time scaling, duality. Understanding these properties.
Examples of Fourier Transform applications: frequency analysis, filtering.
Introduction to filtering. Frequency response of a system. Ideal filters.
Low-pass, high-pass, band-pass, band-stop filters. Basic characteristics and applications.
Brief overview of filter design considerations: passband ripple, stopband attenuation.
